title: Jim McDonnell (boxer)
text:
Jim McDonnell (born 12 September 1960) is a British former <a href="Boxing">boxer</a> who won the European <a href="featherweight">featherweight</a> title and twice fought for World titles at <a href="super%20featherweight">super featherweight</a>.
Career.
Amateur.
He represented <a href="England%20at%20the%201982%20Commonwealth%20Games">England</a> and won a <a href="silver%20medal">silver medal</a> in the lightweight division, at the <a href="1982%20Commonwealth%20Games">1982 Commonwealth Games</a> in <a href="Brisbane">Brisbane</a>, <a href="Queensland">Queensland</a>, <a href="Australia">Australia</a>. He won the 1982 <a href="England%20Boxing">Amateur Boxing Association</a> British <a href="England%20Boxing%20National%20Amateur%20Championships%20Lightweight%20Champions">lightweight title</a>, when boxing out of the St. Pancras ABC.
Professional.
Born in London and a <a href="Janitor">caretaker</a> working for <a href="Camden%20London%20Borough%20Council">Camden Council</a> outside of boxing, McDonnell made his professional debut in March 1983 with a points win over Phil Duke. In March 1985 he beat <a href="Clyde%20Ruan">Clyde Ruan</a> to take the <a href="BBBofC">BBBofC</a> Southern Area featherweight title, a fight that was also a British title eliminator.
The British title fight didn't materialise but in November 1985 he faced <a href="Jose%20Luis%20Vicho">Jose Luis Vicho</a> for the vacant European featherweight title; McDonnell stopped the Spaniard in the fourth round to become European champion. He successfully defended the European title in July 1986 against <a href="Salvatore%20Bottiglieri">Salvatore Bottiglieri</a>, taking a points decision.
By 1988 he had moved up to super featherweight and still with a 100% record from 24 fights fought South African <a href="Brian%20Mitchell%20%28boxer%29">Brian Mitchell</a> for the latter's <a href="World%20Boxing%20Association">WBA</a> super featherweight title in November. The fight went the full twelve rounds but Mitchell won via a comfortable unanimous decision, the first defeat of McDonnell's career.
McDonnell returned in March 1989 with a points win over <a href="Benjie%20Marquez">Benjie Marquez</a>, and in May of that year faced <a href="Barry%20McGuigan">Barry McGuigan</a> at the <a href="G-Mex%20Centre">G-Mex Centre</a>, Manchester. Although the underdog, McDonnell dominated the fight and won after it was stopped in the fourth round due to a cut over McGuigan's right eye. The defeat effectively ended McGuigan's career.
In November 1989 McDonnell got a second shot at a World title when he challenged for <a href="Azumah%20Nelson">Azumah Nelson</a>'s <a href="World%20Boxing%20Council">WBC</a> super featherweight title at the <a href="Royal%20Albert%20Hall">Royal Albert Hall</a>. Nelson had McDonnell down four times and stopped him in the twelfth and final round.
He returned in September 1990 when he was stopped by future WBF World champion <a href="Kenny%20Vice">Kenny Vice</a> in the fourth round. After more than seven years out of the ring, and at the age of 38, he returned in February 1998 against Peter Feher, losing a six-round points decision.
Personal life.
After retiring from boxing he worked as a painter and decorator, ran a gym in <a href="London%20Borough%20of%20Camden">Camden</a>, and became a trainer, most notably working with <a href="Danny%20Williams%20%28boxer%29">Danny Williams</a> and <a href="James%20DeGale">James DeGale</a>. He also ran the <a href="London%20Marathon">London Marathon</a> several times, his best time 2 hours 49 minutes.
